\title{Contextuality in a Deterministic Theory}


\date{January 15, 2016}
\makebeamertitle
\begin{frame}{Motivation}

\begin{itemize}
\item Two theories: Quantum Mechanics (QM) \& Bohmian Mechanics (BM).
\end{itemize}

\pause{}
\begin{itemize}
\item Fundamental difference: BM is deterministic, viz. positions ($q$)
and momenta ($p$) are well defined.
\end{itemize}

\pause{}
\begin{itemize}
\item Initial Aim: Construct a theoretical situation that defies determinism
using QM and analyse using BM.
\end{itemize}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}[allowframebreaks]{Notation}

\begin{defn}
Notation: 

(a) $\psi\in\mathcal{H}$ would typically represent the quantum mechanical
state of the system (assumed pure),

(b) $\hat{\mathcal{H}}$ is defined to mean $\mathcal{H}\otimes\mathcal{H}^{\dagger}$,

(c) $[\mathcal{H}]$ is defined to mean $(\mathcal{H},\,\mathbb{R}^{\otimes})$,
which represents the state of the system including hidden variables, 

(d) $[\psi]\in[\mathcal{H}]$ will represent the state of the system,
including hidden variables, 

(e) a prediction map is $m:\hat{\mathcal{H}},[\mathcal{H}]\to\mathbb{R}$, 

(f) a sequence map is $s:\hat{\mathcal{H}},[\mathcal{H}],\mathbb{R}\to[\mathcal{H}]$, 

(g) the set of all experimental setups is denoted by $\mathcal{E}$, 

(h) a setup map is $e:\hat{\mathcal{H}}\to\mathcal{E}$.
\end{defn}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}[allowframebreaks]{Determinism Tests}

\begin{thm}
Let a map $m:\hat{\mathcal{H}}\to\mathbb{R}$, be s.t. (a) $m(\hat{\mathbb{I}})=1$,
(b) $m(f(\hat{A}_{1},\hat{A}_{2},\dots))=f(m(\hat{A}_{1}),m(\hat{A}_{2}),\dots)$,
for any arbitrary function $f$, where $\hat{A}_{i}$ are arbitrary
Hermitian operators. If $m$ is assumed to describe the outcomes of
measurements, then no $m$ exists which is consistent with all predictions
of Quantum Mechanics.


\end{thm}

Proof (GHZ \cite{GHZ}):
\begin{itemize}
\item 3 observers with one particle each. 
\item Two properties, $X$ and $Y$, with outcomes $\pm1$. 
\item State $\sqrt{2}\left|\chi_{G}\right\rangle =\left|000\right\rangle -\left|111\right\rangle $ 
\item $\hat{A}:=\hat{\sigma}_{x}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{y}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{y}$,
$\hat{A}\left|\chi_{G}\right\rangle =\left|\chi_{G}\right\rangle $,
$\hat{B}:=\hat{\sigma}_{y}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{x}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{y}$
and $\hat{C}:=\hat{\sigma}_{y}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{y}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{z}$;
$\implies m(\hat{A})=m(\hat{B})=m(\hat{C})=+1.$
\end{itemize}

\begin{eqnarray*}
m(\hat{A})m(\hat{B})m(\hat{C}) & = & 1\\
\implies1=m(\hat{A}\hat{B}\hat{C}) & = & m(\hat{\sigma}_{x}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{y}\hat{\sigma}_{x}\hat{\sigma}_{y}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{x})\\
 & = & m(\hat{\sigma}_{x}^{(1)})m(\hat{\sigma}_{y}^{(2)}\hat{\sigma}_{x}^{(2)}\hat{\sigma}_{y}^{(2)})m(\hat{\sigma}_{x}^{(3)})\\
 & = & m(\hat{\sigma}_{x}^{(1)})m(\hat{\sigma}_{x}^{(2)})m(\hat{\sigma}_{x}^{(3)})\\
 & = & m(\hat{D}\equiv\hat{\sigma}_{x}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{x}\otimes\hat{\sigma}_{x}),
\end{eqnarray*}

\begin{itemize}
\item where $\hat{\sigma}_{x}^{(1)}\equiv\hat{\sigma}_{x}\otimes\hat{\mathbb{I}}\otimes\hat{\mathbb{I}}$
and so on.
\item However, $\hat{D}\left|\chi_{G}\right\rangle =-\left|\chi_{G}\right\rangle $,
$\implies m(\hat{D})=-1$.
\item Contradiction!
\end{itemize}
\end{frame}

\begin{frame}[allowframebreaks]{Contextuality Tests}

\begin{thm}
Let a map $m:\hat{\mathcal{H}}\to\mathbb{R}$, be s.t. (a) $m(\hat{\mathbb{I}})=1$,
(b) $m(f(\hat{B}_{1},\hat{B}_{2},\dots))=f(m(\hat{B}_{1}),m(\hat{B}_{2}),\dots)$,
for any arbitrary function $f$, where $\hat{B}_{i}$ are mutually
commuting Hermitian operators. If $m$ is assumed to describe the
outcomes of measurements, then no $m$ exists which is consistent
with all predictions of Quantum Mechanics.
\end{thm}




Proof (new): GHZ generalized


Proof (Mermin's \cite{Mermin}): 

\end{frame}
